newsitem.title: INDIA: INDIA'S UNITED FRONT TO MEET ON AUGUST 13.
newsitem.headline: INDIA'S UNITED FRONT TO MEET ON AUGUST 13.

text.p: India's ruling United Front coalition has scheduled a meeting of its decision-making Steering Committee for August 13, alliance officials said on Monday.
The Steering Committee will consider proposals for reducing the burgeoning cost of subsidies on petroleum products at the meeting, the Press Trust of India (PTI) said.
The 15-party United Front has repeatedly put off a decision on how to tackle a 155 billion rupee ($4.34 billion) bill it owes state-run oil firms.
The bill represents the cumulative amount the government owes the firms to cover the difference between world prices and the subsidised prices which consumers pay for some petroleum products.
Earlier on Monday, a senior Petroleum Ministry official said the government planned to pay off the debt through the issue of 10-year bonds.
But as the deficit on the oil pool account is continuing to grow, the government must also consider ways to prevent the debt from accumulating anew.

A panel of senior-most civil servants of the departments of petroleum, revenue, expenditure and Planning Commission were to consider on Monday ways to bridge the deficit of 92.07 billion rupees projected for 1997/98 (April-March).
Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral and Finance Minister P. Chidambaram have said the prices of some petroleum products might have to be raised to plug the cost of the subsidy programme.
But the leftwing parties in the coalition, led by the communists, have come out firmly against any rise in prices.
